# Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

Search: id:a059773
Showing 1-1 of 1

%I A059773
%S A059773 1,1,2,6,4,6,6,168,48,20,10,24,12,42,8,20160,16,432,18,40,42,110,22,
%T A059773 336,480,156,11232,84,28,120,30,9999360,20,272,24,864,36,342,156,672,
%U A059773 40,252,42,220,192,506,46,40320,2016,12000,32,312,52,303264,110,1008
%N A059773 Maximum size of Aut(G) where G is a finite group of order n.
%C A059773 If n = 2^k then take G to be (Z/2Z)^k, the Abelian group with n=2^k elements and characteristic two. It is generated by any k linearly independent (non-identity) elements, so the automorphism group has size (n-1)(n-2)(n-4)...(n-2^(k-1)), which grows as n^log n. I think one can show that this is optimal for n=2^k and furthermore that this has the highest rate of growth for any infinite sequence of n's. - _Michael Kleber_, Feb 21 2001
%C A059773 Equals A061350(n) for n in A056867. - _Eric M. Schmidt_, Mar 02 2013
%H A059773 Eric M. Schmidt, <a href="/A059773/b059773.txt">Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..767</a>
%e A059773 The corresponding groups are 1, Z2, Z3, (Z2)^2, Z5, S3, Z7, (Z2)^3, (Z3)^2, D5, Z11, A4, Z13, D7, Z15, (Z2)^4, Z17, ...
%o A059773 (GAP) A059773 := function(n) local max, f, i; if IsPrimePowerInt(n) then f := PrimePowersInt(n); return Product([0..f[2]-1], k->n-f[1]^k); fi; max := 1; for i in [1..NumberSmallGroups(n)] do max := Maximum(max, Size(AutomorphismGroup(SmallGroup(n,i)))); od; return max; end; # _Eric M. Schmidt_, Mar 02 2013
%Y A059773 Cf. A061350.
%K A059773 nonn,nice
%O A059773 1,3
%A A059773 _Victor S. Miller_, Feb 21 2001
%E A059773 More terms from Ahmed Fares (ahmedfares(AT)my-deja.com), Jun 09 2001
%E A059773 a(18)-a(56) from _Stephen A. Silver_, Feb 26 2013
